story_arc.closing_state: Transitioning authority to Hannah; watching with heartbreak as Menahem chose violence; completing legacy of protection and preservation

thematic_significance: Archive keeping as preservation of witness
Grace and free will: does grace determine response or do those saved remain free to reject salvation?
character.why_readers_care: Margaret represents the power of protective love and the cost of that protection. Her character demonstrates how one moment of divine intervention—throwing herself between children and soldiers—transformed her entire life into a mission of protection. Readers watch her raise two children she saved, one choosing grace (Hannah) and one choosing violence (Menahem), embodying the ultimate theological question: does grace determine response, or do those saved remain free to reject salvation? Through Margaret, readers see how loss can be transformed into protection, how maternal love extends to community, and how archives preserve witness that would otherwise be lost.
character_questions_for_readers: Does grace determine response, or do those saved remain free to reject salvation?
Can protective love save someone who chooses violence?
How does loss transform into protection?
What is the cost of being the one who saves others?
How do we preserve witness when systems seek to erase it?
